History of Present Illness:
69 yo M self-referred to Dr.[**Name (NI) 23346**] office for evaluation of
left face defect and for suggestions to improve his
reconstruction of this area.  He had previous reconstruction
following excision of advanced local melanoma on left face.  His
melanoma was diagnosed ~8years ago and has undergone multiple
surgeries to remove it with negative margins.  He has had ~[**6-28**]
reconstructive procedures.  His left cheek reconstruction was
performed using a scalp flap.  He has poor left eye vision and
corneal irritation.  He has a small fistula into the left
nasopharynx at the lateral aspect of the left ala.

Past Medical History:
Malignant Melanoma diagnosed ~8years ago
s/p multiple surgeries to remove melanoma (still residual
melanoma with metastases)
s/p multiple facial reconstructive surgeries
s/p chemotherapy and radiation therapy

Imaging:
CTA HEAD W&W/O C & RECONS; CTA NECK W&W/OC & RECONS
Contrast: OPTIRAY

[**Hospital 93**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
69 year old man w/ metastatic melanoma s/p L facial flap
revision w/ continued bleeding
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
PLEASE DO CTA HEAD AND NECK W/ WIDE COVERAGE TO INCLUDE SURGICAL
AREA (LEFT NASAL/MAXILLA REGION) AND PLEASE DO NON-CONTRAST
STUDY BEFORE CTA, ? eval bleeding source
CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None.

CLINICAL INFORMATION: Metastatic melanoma with left facial flap
revision and continued bleeding.

NON-CONTRAST HEAD CT.

FINDINGS: Examination was performed with a standard soft tissue
algorithm and does not well evaluate the brain parenchyma.
Ill-defined abnormality in the left middle cranial fossa is seen
consistent with findings on [**2167-1-3**] on the MRI study of
enhancing mass with adjacent edema of the temporal lobe and
malacic change. There is bone destruction of the anterior aspect
of the left maxillary sinus and of the left ethmoid sinus. There
is opacification of the left frontal sinus. There is an
abnormality in the left side of the nasal cavity presumably
representing a nasal pack. There is opacification of the left
side of the sphenoid sinus. There is an air fluid level in the
left maxillary sinus. There is evidence of prior surgery on the
left medial maxillary wall. There is opacification of the left
mastoid sinus. These findings are probably similar to the MRI
study of [**1-3**].

CT angiogram of the cervical vessels and intracranial
circulation. There is no evidence of significant internal
carotid artery stenosis. There is some abnormality medially at
the left lung apex which might represent atelectasis but raises
the question of prior radiation therapy in this region.
Intracranially, there is no evidence of aneurysm or flow
abnormality. On the raw data series, there is no definite
evidence of abnormal pooling of contrast material in the region
of the facial flap or of the nasal pack in the left nasal
cavity. Metallic clip is visualized into the left greater
eminence presumably related to the surgery.

IMPRESSION: No obvious bleeding site in the left face or nasal
cavity. No evidence of internal carotid artery stenosis or
intracranial aneurysm. Deformity of left-sided facial bones as
described with considerable abnormal soft tissue. Opacification
of left mastoid sinus. Abnormality in left middle cranial fossa
consistent with the findings on the MRI study.

DR. [**First Name (STitle) 23303**] [**Doctor Last Name **]
Approved: WED [**2167-1-7**] 11:40 AM



MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST  [**2167-1-3**] 7:13 PM
Reason: metastatic w/u history of brain metastases with melanoma

Contrast: MAGNEVIST

[**Hospital 93**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
69 year old man with melanoma and change in MS
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
metastatic w/u history of brain metastases with melanoma
MR HEAD

INDICATION: 69-year-old male with melanoma and change in mental
status.

TECHNIQUE: Sagittal T1. Axial T1, T2, FLAIR, gradient echo,
diffusion. Postgadolinium T1-weighted images in three planes.

No prior studies available for comparison at this institution.

FINDINGS: There is an enhancing mass involving the left temporal
lobe, which measures approximately 4.0 x 3.8 cm. The mass abuts
the ventricle, but there is no subependymal enhancement at this
time. There is involvement of the anterior clivus on the left.
The mass surrounds the cavernous segment of the left internal
carotid artery and probably involves the left cavernous sinus
and abuts Meckel's cave on the left. Abnormal enhancing tissue
also abuts the orbital apex on the left but does not appear to
invade the orbit itself. The mass extends inferior into the
infratemporal fossa and involves the masseter space with a large
area of amorphous abnormal enhancing soft tissue. There is also
diffuse involvement of the temporal bone on the left with
abnormal enhancing tissue. The mass also extends anteriorly to
involve the left sphenoid sinus as well as the nasal cavity on
the left. There is extensive abnormal soft tissue in the soft
tissues overlying the left maxilla, which extends across the
superior alveolar ridge to involve a small portion of the soft
tissues overlying the right maxilla.

There are inspissated secretions noted in the left frontal sinus
as well as an air-fluid level in the left maxillary sinus.

IMPRESSION: Extensive abnormal enhancing soft tissue involving
the brain, infratemporal fossa, temporal bone, sphenoid sinus as
well as the nasal cavity and the maxillary regions anteriorly.
For full description, please see the above body of the report.
If the patient has prior examinations, these would be extremely
helpful for comparison to determine whether there has been
progression of disease.

The study and the report were reviewed by the staff radiologist.
DR. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]
DR. [**First Name (STitle) 61688**] [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **]
Approved: MON [**2167-1-5**] 11:55 AM

OPERATIVE REPORT

Name:  [**Known lastname **], [**Known firstname 275**]              Unit No:  [**Numeric Identifier 67931**]
Service:  PSU                     Date:  [**2167-1-1**]
Date of Birth:  [**2097-10-8**]        Sex:  M
Surgeon:  [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 67932**], MD 2918
ASSISTANT:  [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 24333**], INT
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1.  Status post malignant melanoma of the left maxilla.
2.  Status post flap transfer right fact to left cheek.
3.  Oral incontinence with elevated left upper lip.
4.  Left seventh and fifth nerve paralysis.
5.  Maxillary cutaneous fistula of left side of face.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1.  Status post malignant melanoma of the left maxilla.
2.  Status post flap transfer right face to left cheek.
3.  Oral incontinence with elevated left upper lip.
4.  Left seventh and fifth nerve paralysis.
5.  Maxillary cutaneous fistula of left side of face.

OPERATION PERFORMED:
1.  Debulking of fasciocutaneous flap to the left the cheek
    with advancement.
2.  Closure of maxillocutaneous. elevation repositioning of
    upper lip left upper lip

ANESTHESIA:  General endotracheal anesthesia.

HISTORICAL NOTE:  [**Known firstname **] [**Known lastname **] is a very unfortunate young
man who initially presented to his dermatologist with a small
lesion on the left cheek. This was subsequently cauterized on
several occasions and kept on recurring. Biopsy eventually
revealed a malignant melanoma for which he has been treated
with a radical head and neck resection and resurfacing with a
pedicle flap based on the superficial temporal vessels. At
the present time he has extensive intracerebral metastases
which have been treated with radiation therapy. He is awake,
alert, coherent without significant neurologic deficits. The
main problems have been continued drainage from the maxillary
cutaneous fistula, left side of his cheek as well as an
inability to close his lips of hold fluid in due to the
elevation of the left upper lip. He is brought to the
operating room today knowing full well that he does have
metastatic disease for lowering of the upper lip and
redirection of the fistula into the nasal cavity. The
significant debulking of biscuited flap in the left cheek was
also done and this provided enough tissue to reroute the
sinus.

PROCEDURE:  With the patient on the operating room table in
the supine position with the head tilted degrees, general
endotracheal anesthetic was induced without difficulty. Full
head and neck prepping and draping was then done. Appropriate
digital pics were taken. The lines for the incisions were
then marked out at the base of the previous flap transfer to
the left cheek. Following this, this area to be dissected was
and injected with 4 cc of 1% lidocaine plus epinephrine. When
a good epinephrine affect had been achieved, an incision was
made around from 9 o'clock to 10 o'clock around the inferior
portion of the rather biscuited flap of the left cheek.
Dissection progressed down to the maxilla and the soft tissue
attached to the maxilla was then undermined down to the level
of the roots of the teeth. Care was taken not to break into
the lingual sulcus of the upper lip. However, this
significantly allowed lower repositioning of the upper lip.
The excess bulk of soft tissue was then excised from the flap
which was fairly thick. We were able to excise tissue from
the inferior two to fifth of the flap, superior portion,
which contained a vascular pedicle and was kept anatomically
intact. This extended up into the lower lip region.

Once the debulking had been done, the flap could then be
rotated medially and inferiorly over a significant
difference. The cutaneous fistula was then addressed. The
lining of the sinus was excised and with this we were able to
elevate the cheek flap more and while tangentially excising
much of this excess tissue we encountered tannish whitish
almost gelatinous tissue which did not appear normal but we
were not surprised that the frozen section on this biopsy was
consistent with a malignant spindle cell type tumor.
We are assuming that much of the maxillary sinus is filled
with this tissue. The cheek flap was then brought down and
was rotated medially toward the left side of the nose and
inferiorly. A layered closure was used inferiorly, first
anchoring the lip tissue down with 3-0 Vicryl sutures and
then insetting the flap in layers using 5-0 Vicryl and 5-0
running intracuticular Monocryl suture. This was then
reinforced with multiple simple everting interrupted 5-0
nylon sutures. The ala of the nose which was pulled inward
and internally compresses was then released. This was then
sutured to the medial aspect of the cheek flap which had been
rotated into the nose. This then allowed redirection of the
sinus into the nasal cavity. This area was closed with Vicryl
and 5-0 nylon sutures.

Preoperatively we had planned on doing a medial canthopexy to
correct the severe medial ectropion of the eye.
Preoperatively he was unduly swollen and this I am sure is
due to the tumor in the area. We did not release and skin
graft this area today. This was not his [**Last Name 16423**] problem. At the
end of the procedure a light compression dressing was
applied. He was then awakened and returned to the recovery
room in satisfactory condition. He will remain as an
inpatient overnight.

                        [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 122**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 5385**], [**MD Number(1) 24266**]

[**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 58533**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 12444**].
  [**-6/2689**]  Consult slides referred to Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **].
DIAGNOSIS:
1.  Skin, face, tissue for frozen section (A):
Spindle cell neoplasm, consistent with spindle cell/desmoplastic
melanoma (see note).
2.  Skin, face, tissue for permanent section (B-C):
Spindle cell neoplasm, consistent with spindle cell/desmoplastic
melanoma, extending to specimen margin (see note).
3.  Skin, left cheek plaque, tissue for permanent section (D-F):
Spindle cell neoplasm, consistent with spindle cell/desmoplastic
melanoma, extending to specimen margin (see note).

Note: The findings are consistent recurrent spindle
cell/desmoplastic melanoma in a patient with known history of
melanoma at this site.

*Per clinical note in computer, this patient originally had a
lentigo maligna melanoma, desmoplastic neurotropic type, S-100
and Mart-1 positive, diagnosed at [**Hospital6 1129**]
in [**2158**].

Clinical:  Malignant melanoma on face.
Gross:  The specimen is received fresh, labeled with "[**Known firstname **]
[**Known lastname **]" and the medical record number.
Part 1 is received in the O.R., additionally labeled "malignant
melanoma", and consists of a tan piece of tissue that measures
0.7 x 0.5 x 0.4 cm, which is entirely submitted for frozen
section diagnosis.  Intraoperative frozen section diagnosis by
Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **] reads:  "Recurrent spindle cell neoplasm". The
entire frozen section remnant is submitted in cassette A.
Part 2 is additionally labeled "malignant melanoma permanent"
and consists of two pieces of pink to tan soft tissue that
measure in aggregate 2.5 x 2 x 1.8 cm.  The specimen is inked in
black.  It is serially-sectioned to reveal areas of tan
'papillations' that measure up to 1.2 cm. The entire specimen is
submitted in B-C.
Part 3 is additionally labeled "plaque left cheek" and consists
of a 3.5 x 1.8 x 0.7 cm piece of fibrous and adipose tissue with
focal areas of hemorrhage. No masses are identified. The
specimen is inked in black and sectioned to reveal unremarkable
fibrous tissue. The entire specimen is submitted in D-F.





Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted and underwent left facial flap revision
on [**2167-1-1**] (please refer to operative note for details).  The
patient tolerated the procedure well and was initially on
experiencing mild bloody drainage from his left nostril and was
transferred to the floor.  However, the bleeding was persistent
despite numerous gauze, surgicel, merocel packings and pressure
dressings.  His hematocrit was monitored daily and was overall
stable without transfusion.  His electrolytes were checked on
[**1-3**] secondary to an episode of confusion.  His sodium level
was 118.  He was placed on 1 liter fluid restriction daily and
serum/urine osmolarities were sent (Serum Osm =248; Urine Osm
=463).  His hyponatremia resolved on fluid restriction and his
sodium was in normal range at discharge.

The oncology service was consulted for and the patient was seen
on [**1-3**].  They explained to the patient that would follow-up
with him in clinic to continue discussion of systemic therapy
when he had recovered from surgery.  They attributed his
longstanding memory problems to radiation damage.  They agreed
with fluid restriction for his hyponatremia.

The neurology service was consulted and they saw the patient on
[**1-3**].  Their recommendations in agreement with the fluid
restriction for his hyponatremia.  However, they did not believe
the hyponatremia was related to the carbamazepine as he had been
on a stable dose for several years.  In addition, based on
history this medication was for trigeminal neuralgia and not for
seizures.  They commented on the presence of extensive signal
abnormalities in the left temporal lobe and questioned tumor
recurrence vs. radiation necrosis.

The medicine service was consulted for his hyponatremia and they
were in agreement with fluid restriction and also recommended
repeating labs daily and not to give hypertonic saline.

He was seen by the ENT surgeons on [**1-5**] and they placed his
current merocel packing.  They recommended to keep the packing
in for now and to use Afrin for 4 days.  They believed that the
bleeding appeared to be coming from necrotic or neoplastic
mucosa, which may not heal normally and therefore, were
concerned that when packs are removed, the tissue will continue
bleeding.  This led to the pursuit of neuroembolization for
definitive management.  Neuroembolization of the left maxillary
artery was performed on [**1-6**] by the neurointerventional
radiologists.  However, despite the successful embolization, the
patient continued to have a slow bleed around the nasal packing.
 The patient was admitted directly to the SICU after the
procedure as a precaution.  But he did well post-procedure and
was soon transferred back to the floor.

After discussions between Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5385**], Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 67935**] (patient's PCP
at [**Name9 (PRE) 2025**]) and the patient, it was decided that the patient would
go home and follow-up with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 67935**] within one week for
further management coordination.  The patient was in agreement
was discharged home on [**1-7**] in overall stable condition with
the nasal packing intact.  He and his friend were instructed to
call/return to [**Hospital1 18**] if there were any increase in bleeding or
if the patient became symptomatic.

Medications on Admission:

Provigil 200mg daily

Discharge Instructions:
Please resume your home medications and take your new
medications as prescribed.  [**Last Name (un) **] do not remove your nasal
packing and change outside dressing only as needed.  Please Dr. [**Name (NI) 67936**] ([**0-0-**]) or Dr.[**Name (NI) 67937**] office/return to [**Hospital1 18**]
if you experience persistent fever, pain, increasing bleeding,
increasing difficulty breathing, nausea/vomiting.  Please see
Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 67935**] within 1 week.

Followup Instructions:
Please follow-up with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 67935**] within a week - please call
his office for an appointment [**Telephone/Fax (1) 67938**].  Please follow-up
with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5385**] in [**1-20**] weeks/as needed.
